safety_notes: Have spouse present during all standing exercises
Stop immediately if experiencing dizziness - sit down and wait 5 minutes
Use wall or chair for support at all times during balance work
Monitor blood pressure before exercise (should be below 140/90)
Take frequent breaks every 5-7 minutes as needed
Watch for signs of overexertion due to blood thinner medication

exercises.name: Seated Marching
exercises.description: Gentle warm-up to activate hip flexors and improve leg coordination, with special focus on left leg movement awareness
steps: Sit tall in chair with back supported, feet flat on floor hip-width apart
Place hands on armrests for stability
Lift RIGHT knee up 2-3 inches, hold for 2 seconds while breathing out
Lower right foot slowly and controlled
Lift LEFT knee up 2-3 inches (use hands to gently assist under thigh if needed), hold 2 seconds
Lower left foot slowly
Continue alternating, spending extra mental focus on the left leg movement
tips: Keep shoulders level and centered - don't lean to either side
It's normal for left leg to lift lower than right - any movement is progress
Use your right hand to help lift left leg if needed
Focus your attention on what the left leg is doing - this brain connection is important
If you feel any dizziness, stop and rest
exercises.easier: Just slide left foot forward and back on floor instead of lifting (marching in place)
exercises.harder: Lift knee 4-5 inches higher, or try without using hands to assist left leg
warnings: Stop if you feel dizzy or lightheaded
Don't hold your breath - keep breathing naturally
Ensure chair is stable and won't slide

exercises.name: Seated Weight Shifts (Side to Side)
exercises.description: Core balance exercise to improve weight distribution awareness and prepare for standing balance - critical for reducing fall risk
equipment: Sturdy chair without armrests (or sit forward away from armrests)
steps: Sit toward front half of chair, feet flat and hip-width apart
Place hands on thighs, sit up tall with shoulders back
Feel equal weight on both sitting bones to start
Slowly shift weight to RIGHT hip over 3 seconds, keep shoulders level
Hold right side shift for 5 seconds, feeling the pressure under right sitting bone
Return to center over 3 seconds
Slowly shift weight to LEFT hip over 3 seconds - you may need to think about this more consciously
Hold left side shift for 7-10 seconds (extra time on affected side helps brain relearn)
Return to center
Repeat the cycle
tips: This is about QUALITY not speed - slow controlled movements are best
Imagine you're moving from your hips, not leaning your upper body
Spend that extra time on the left side - your brain needs more practice there
If available, practice in front of a mirror to see if shoulders stay level
Your spouse can place a gentle hand on your shoulder to remind you to stay upright
exercises.easier: Make smaller weight shifts (only 25-30% of weight), or keep hands on armrests for confidence
exercises.harder: Increase hold time to 10 seconds each side, or try lifting the opposite foot 1 inch during the hold
warnings: Don't shift so far that you feel unstable or might fall
Keep both feet planted firmly on floor throughout
Stop if you experience hip or lower back pain

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps (Both Legs)
exercises.description: Improve ankle mobility and lower leg circulation - important for walking and reducing swelling
steps: Sit comfortably with feet flat on floor
Keeping heels on the ground, lift both sets of toes up toward ceiling
Hold the 'toes up' position for 2 seconds, feeling calf stretch
Point both sets of toes down toward floor
Hold the 'toes down' position for 2 seconds
Return to neutral and repeat
After finishing both legs together, do 5 extra pumps with LEFT ankle only for additional practice
tips: Move through the fullest range of motion that's comfortable
The left ankle might move less than right - that's expected
You can use your right hand to gently move left foot through the motion if needed
Keep the movement slow and controlled
This helps prevent blood clots, especially important given your medications
exercises.easier: Smaller range of motion, or do one ankle at a time starting with right
exercises.harder: Add 5 ankle circles in each direction after the pumps
warnings: Stop if you experience calf cramping - stand and gently walk it off
Avoid this exercise if you have acute ankle pain

exercises.name: Supported Standing Hold (Chair Support)
exercises.description: Build standing balance confidence and leg strength - essential progression toward walking without cane
steps: SETUP: Have spouse standing beside you, chair in front, wall to one side
Start seated, place both hands firmly on chair back or armrests
Lean forward slightly, shift weight onto feet
Push through legs to stand up, using arms for support as much as needed
Once standing, adjust hand position to lightly hold chair back
Stand tall, distribute weight as evenly as possible on both feet (you may feel more on right - that's normal)
Hold this position, breathing normally, focusing on feeling the floor under BOTH feet
To finish: slowly bend knees and lower back to seated position with control
tips: This is your most important exercise - it directly addresses fall risk
Don't rush the stand-up or sit-down - these transitions are where falls happen
Try to feel equal weight on both feet, even if left leg feels weaker
Look straight ahead, not down at your feet
Your spouse should stay within arm's reach but let you do the work
If 15 seconds feels easy, that's great - we'll progress you next week
exercises.easier: Hold for only 5-10 seconds, or keep more weight on hands/use counter that's higher
exercises.harder: Hold for 20-30 seconds, or lighten pressure on hands (fingertips only)
warnings: DO NOT attempt if feeling dizzy or unstable today
Always have spouse or support person present
Sit down immediately if you feel unsteady, dizzy, or weak
Never attempt this exercise alone in week 1

exercises.name: Seated Upper Body & Shoulder Stretches
exercises.description: Gentle cool-down focusing on left shoulder mobility and reducing tension - addresses your shoulder discomfort
steps: Sit comfortably, feet flat on floor
Shoulder rolls: Roll both shoulders backward in large circles 5 times, then forward 5 times
Neck stretches: Gently tilt right ear toward right shoulder, hold 15 seconds, repeat left side (may need to use right hand to gently support left side of head)
Left arm pendulum: Lean slightly forward, let left arm hang, gently swing it forward/back like a pendulum 10 times
Seated spinal twist: Place right hand on left knee, gently twist to look over left shoulder, hold 20 seconds, repeat other side
Deep breathing: 5 slow, deep breaths - in through nose (4 counts), out through mouth (6 counts)
tips: Never force any stretch - gentle pulling sensation only
The left shoulder may be tighter - that's normal, be patient with it
Breathe deeply during all stretches
This is recovery time - think about how your body feels after the workout
The deep breathing helps lower blood pressure naturally
exercises.easier: Shorter hold times (10 seconds), or skip the spinal twist
exercises.harder: Add arm circles with both arms, or hold stretches for 30 seconds
warnings: Stop any stretch that causes sharp pain
Don't force the left shoulder - it will improve gradually
Avoid if experiencing acute shoulder injury

exercises.name: Seated Knee Extensions
exercises.description: Strengthen quadriceps muscles essential for standing, walking, and stair climbing
steps: Sit tall with back supported, hands on armrests or thighs
Starting with RIGHT leg: straighten knee to lift foot off ground, pointing toes up
Hold with leg fully extended for 3 seconds, squeeze thigh muscle
Lower slowly over 3 seconds with control
Complete all right leg reps, then switch to LEFT leg
For left leg: may need to use hands under thigh to help initiate the lift, then try to hold it yourself
Focus on straightening the left knee as much as possible, even if foot doesn't lift as high
tips: The lowering phase is just as important as the lifting - don't let leg drop
Left leg will likely be weaker - any lift is success, even if knee doesn't fully straighten
Keep back against chair, don't lean forward
Point toes toward ceiling to maximize quad engagement
This exercise directly helps with standing up from chairs and getting out of bed
exercises.easier: Don't straighten knee all the way, or reduce reps to 6-8 per leg
exercises.harder: Add 1-2 lb ankle weight, or hold extension for 5 seconds
warnings: Stop if experiencing knee pain (mild muscle fatigue is OK)
Don't lock knee joint forcefully

exercises.name: Seated Hip Abduction (Leg Out to Side)
exercises.description: Strengthen hip muscles important for balance and sideways stability while walking
steps: Sit tall toward front of chair, hands on armrests for support
Keep right leg planted, lift and move LEFT leg out to the side 6-8 inches
Hold for 2 seconds, then bring back to center with control
Complete all left leg reps first (affected side)
Then switch: keep left leg planted, move RIGHT leg out to side
Focus on moving from the hip, keeping knee pointing forward
tips: We're starting with left leg because it needs more practice
Don't lean away as leg goes out - stay upright
Left leg may not go as far - that's expected and will improve
You can use resistance band around thighs if you have one for extra challenge
This helps with getting in/out of cars and walking on uneven surfaces
exercises.easier: Slide foot out to side on floor instead of lifting, or reduce range to 3-4 inches
exercises.harder: Add resistance band around knees, or increase hold to 4 seconds
warnings: Stop if experiencing hip or groin pain
Keep movements controlled - don't swing leg

exercises.name: Sit-to-Stand Practice (Partial Stands)
exercises.description: Practice the motion of standing up - one of the most important functional movements for independence
steps: Sit toward front edge of chair, feet flat and slightly behind knees
Lean forward so nose is over toes, look ahead not down
Place hands on armrests
Push through legs and arms to stand HALFWAY up (60-70% of standing)
Hold this partial standing position for 2 seconds
Lower back down to seated with CONTROL over 3 seconds
Rest, then repeat
Spouse should stand nearby but only assist if you truly need it
tips: The goal is building strength and control, not standing fully yet
Nose over toes position is KEY - this shifts your weight forward properly
Going down slowly is harder than going up - this builds serious strength
Try to use legs more than arms, even though arms are helping
By week 4, you'll be doing full stands without hands!
exercises.easier: Stand up only 30-40%, or use arms more for assistance
exercises.harder: Stand up 80-90% of the way, or reduce arm assistance
warnings: Have spouse present for safety
Stop if knees hurt (muscle burn is OK, joint pain is not)
Don't attempt if feeling dizzy today

exercises.name: Heel Raises (Seated)
exercises.description: Strengthen calf muscles needed for walking and balance
steps: Sit with feet flat, hands on thighs or armrests
Keeping toes on ground, lift both heels up as high as comfortable
Hold at the top for 2 seconds, feeling calves contract
Lower heels slowly back to floor
After doing both together, do 5 extra raises with LEFT foot only for additional practice
tips: Lift heels as high as you can - this builds push-off strength for walking
Left calf may be weaker - the extra reps help
Keep movement smooth and controlled
This also helps prevent ankle swelling
exercises.easier: Lower height, or fewer reps (8-10)
exercises.harder: Hold top position for 4 seconds, or add resistance by pressing down on thighs with hands
warnings: Stop if experiencing calf cramping

exercises.name: Gentle Seated Hamstring & Hip Stretches
exercises.description: Cool down and maintain flexibility in legs and hips
steps: Hamstring stretch: Sit on edge of chair, extend right leg straight with heel on floor, lean forward gently until you feel stretch in back of thigh, hold 20 seconds, repeat left leg
Hip flexor stretch: Sit tall, bring right ankle to rest on left knee (figure-4 position), gently press down on right knee, hold 20 seconds, repeat other side (may need help positioning left ankle)
Glute stretch: Hug right knee to chest, hold 15 seconds, repeat left side
Deep breathing: 5 slow breaths to finish
tips: Stretching prevents stiffness and helps with fall prevention
Never bounce - hold steady gentle stretches
Left side may be less flexible - be patient, it will improve
The hip flexor stretch is especially important since you use a cane
exercises.easier: Shorter holds (10-15 seconds), or skip figure-4 if too difficult
exercises.harder: Hold stretches for 30 seconds each
warnings: Stop if any stretch causes sharp pain
Be careful with hip flexor stretch if you have hip replacement

exercises.name: Seated Torso Rotations
exercises.description: Warm up spine and core muscles, improve rotational mobility for daily activities
steps: Sit tall in chair, feet flat on floor
Cross arms over chest or place hands behind head
Keeping hips facing forward, rotate upper body to look over RIGHT shoulder
Hold for 2 seconds, return to center
Rotate to look over LEFT shoulder, hold 2 seconds
Return to center and repeat
Move smoothly and controlled, like you're looking for something behind you
tips: This helps with looking behind when backing up or parking
Keep hips square - only upper body rotates
Breathe normally throughout
If you feel any pinching in back, reduce range of rotation
exercises.easier: Hands on thighs instead of crossed, or smaller rotation
exercises.harder: Hold rotation for 4 seconds, or add side reach at end of rotation
warnings: Stop if experiencing back pain
Move slowly if you have history of vertigo

exercises.name: Seated Weight Shifts (Forward & Back)
exercises.description: Progress balance training by adding front-to-back weight shifts - builds on Day 1's side-to-side work
steps: Sit on front half of chair, feet flat hip-width apart
Start with weight evenly distributed
Slowly lean forward from hips (not rounding back), feel weight shift onto feet
Hold forward lean for 3 seconds
Slowly lean back, pressing into chair back, feel weight shift to tailbone
Hold back lean for 3 seconds
Return to center and repeat
tips: This teaches your body to handle weight shifts when bending or reaching
Keep movements small and controlled - 6-8 inches of lean is plenty
Don't hold your breath - breathe throughout
This directly helps with getting dressed, picking up objects, etc.
exercises.easier: Smaller leans (3-4 inches), or keep hands on armrests
exercises.harder: Increase lean distance, or add arm reach forward at the lean
warnings: Don't lean so far forward you might fall
Stop if dizzy or unstable

exercises.name: Marching with Arm Swing
exercises.description: Coordination exercise combining leg and arm movements - mimics walking pattern
steps: Sit tall, feet flat on floor
Lift RIGHT knee while swinging LEFT arm forward (opposite arm/leg)
Lower right leg while bringing left arm back
Lift LEFT knee while swinging RIGHT arm forward
Lower left leg while bringing right arm back
Continue this alternating pattern, moving smoothly
For left leg lifts, you can make movement smaller if needed
tips: This is harder than it sounds - it requires brain and body coordination
Opposite arm and leg is the natural walking pattern
Left arm may not swing as much - that's OK, focus on any movement
Don't worry if you mix up the pattern - just reset and continue
This exercise is rebuilding walking coordination
exercises.easier: Do legs only first (like Day 1), then add arms when comfortable
exercises.harder: Increase speed slightly, or exaggerate arm swing
warnings: Stop if confused or frustrated - this is a coordination challenge
Don't attempt if feeling dizzy

exercises.name: Standing Weight Shifts (Supported)
exercises.description: Progress to standing balance work - shifting weight while standing with support
steps: Stand facing counter or chair back, both hands lightly holding for support
Spouse standing beside you
Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Slowly shift weight onto RIGHT foot, feeling left foot get lighter (don't lift it)
Hold for 3 seconds
Shift weight back to center (equal weight)
Slowly shift weight onto LEFT foot, feeling right foot get lighter
Hold for 5 seconds (extra time on affected side)
Shift back to center and repeat
tips: This is advanced for week 1 - take your time, there's no rush
You should feel ONE foot bearing most of your weight, but BOTH feet stay on floor
The goal is to prepare you for single-leg stance eventually
Keep hands light on support - you're building independent balance
Your cane uses this same weight-shifting principle
exercises.easier: Hold support more firmly, or reduce hold time to 2 seconds
exercises.harder: Use only fingertips for support, or increase hold to 8 seconds
warnings: MUST have spouse present for this exercise
Stop immediately if dizzy or unstable
Never do this exercise alone in week 1

exercises.name: Seated Side Bends & Stretches
exercises.description: Cool down with gentle lateral stretches for core and obliques
steps: Sit tall, feet flat, right hand on thigh or armrest
Reach left arm up and over head, bending gently to the right side
Hold side bend for 20 seconds, feeling stretch along left side
Return to center
Reach right arm up and over, bend to left side
Hold 20 seconds
Finish with shoulder shrugs: lift both shoulders to ears, hold 3 seconds, release - repeat 5 times
End with 5 deep breaths
tips: These stretches relieve tension from balance work
Left shoulder may feel tighter - be gentle with it
Breathe deeply into the stretched side
Think about how your body feels after today's challenges
exercises.easier: Shorter holds (10 seconds), or skip arm overhead if shoulder hurts
exercises.harder: Hold stretches 30 seconds, or add gentle rotation at end of side bend
warnings: Stop if sharp pain in ribs or back
Don't force left shoulder overhead if painful

exercises.name: Bilateral Shoulder Raises (Both Arms)
exercises.description: Strengthen shoulders and practice lifting arms together - foundation for dressing and reaching
equipment: Optional: light resistance band or very light weights (1-2 lbs)
steps: Sit tall, arms at sides
Keeping arms straight, raise both arms forward and up together to shoulder height
Hold for 2 seconds at shoulder height
Lower slowly with control
After 8 reps forward, do 8 reps lifting arms out to SIDES (like airplane wings)
For all reps, focus on getting left arm to move along with right
tips: Left arm will likely not go as high - that's expected
Use right arm movement as a visual guide for left arm to follow
You can use right hand to gently assist left arm if needed to start movement
This directly helps with putting on shirts, reaching for items on shelves
Don't lift above shoulder height if it causes pain
exercises.easier: Lift arms only halfway (45 degrees), or use right hand to assist left arm more
exercises.harder: Hold resistance band between hands, or use 1-2 lb weights
warnings: Stop if experiencing shoulder pain (left shoulder discomfort is noted)
Don't force left arm beyond comfortable range

exercises.name: Left Arm Assisted Reach & Grasp Practice
exercises.description: Specific exercise for improving left arm function for daily tasks - addresses your goal of better arm function
equipment: Small objects like water bottle, cup, ball
steps: Sit at table with objects placed 8-10 inches in front of you
Use RIGHT hand to help position LEFT hand on table
Starting with left hand on table, slide left arm forward to reach for object
Use right hand to assist left hand in grasping object if needed
Try to participate with left hand in the grasp - even small finger movements count
Hold grasp for 3 seconds
Release and slide left arm back
Repeat, each time asking left arm to do a tiny bit more of the work
tips: This is pure neuroplasticity work - your brain is relearning
Focus intense mental attention on what left arm/hand is doing
Even if right hand does 90% of the work, the 10% from left hand is valuable
Practice with different objects - variety helps learning
Talk yourself through it: 'left arm reach forward, left fingers open, close around cup'
Progress is measured in weeks and months, not minutes - be patient
exercises.easier: Place objects closer (4-6 inches), or let right hand do more of the work
exercises.harder: Place objects farther away (12 inches), or try with left hand only (right hand just hovering for safety)
warnings: Never force left hand closed - let it move at its own pace
Stop if experiencing pain in left shoulder

exercises.name: Sit-to-Stand (Full Stand Practice)
exercises.description: Progress to full standing from seated - building toward independence
steps: Sit toward front of chair, feet slightly behind knees
Lean forward - nose over toes
Hands on armrests
Rock forward and push through legs and arms to FULLY stand up
Stand tall for 2 seconds
Slowly sit back down over 3-4 seconds with CONTROL - don't plop
Rest and repeat
Spouse nearby but letting you do the work
tips: This is your independence exercise - master this and life gets easier
The going down part builds the most strength
Try to use legs as much as possible, arms just assist
This transfers to: getting off toilet, out of car, out of bed
Focus on feeling both legs working, even if right does more
exercises.easier: Only stand 80% of the way, or use arms more
exercises.harder: Use arms less (hands hovering over armrests), or stand from lower chair
warnings: Have spouse present
Stop if knees hurt
Don't attempt if very fatigued or dizzy

exercises.name: Toe Taps (Standing with Support)
exercises.description: Standing balance exercise with leg movement - challenges stability
equipment: Sturdy counter or chair back for support
steps: Stand holding counter with both hands, spouse nearby
Stand on LEFT leg (affected side), lift RIGHT foot 2-3 inches off ground
Tap right toes forward on floor, then tap toes to the side, then tap behind
That's one rep - complete all right leg taps first
Then switch: stand on RIGHT leg, lift LEFT foot and practice taps
Left leg taps will be smaller and that's perfectly fine
Focus on keeping standing leg steady
tips: This teaches standing balance on each leg separately
The standing leg is doing all the work, the tapping leg is just the challenge
When standing on left leg, you can hold support more firmly
This directly prepares you for walking without cane
Don't worry about how high you lift the tapping foot - 1 inch is fine
exercises.easier: Just tap forward only (skip side and back), or hold support firmly with both hands
exercises.harder: Hold support with just one hand, or tap farther away
warnings: MUST have spouse present
Stop if feeling unstable
This is advanced - it's OK if this is hard

exercises.name: Upper Body & Neck Stretches
exercises.description: Cool down focusing on neck, shoulders, and arms after upper body work
steps: Neck rotation: Slowly turn head to look over right shoulder, hold 15 seconds, repeat left
Shoulder stretch: Bring right arm across body, use left hand to gently pull it closer, hold 20 seconds, repeat other side (assist left arm with right hand)
Tricep stretch: Reach right arm overhead, bend elbow so hand goes down back, gently press on right elbow with left hand, hold 15 seconds, repeat (modify for left arm comfort)
Wrist circles: Make circles with both wrists 10 times each direction
Finish: Interlace fingers, stretch arms forward, round upper back, hold 20 seconds
Deep breathing: 5 slow breaths
tips: These stretches prevent stiffness from strength work
Be especially gentle with left shoulder given your pain there
Wrist circles help with hand dexterity
Breathing helps blood pressure stay stable
exercises.easier: Skip tricep stretch if shoulder hurts, shorter holds (10 seconds)
exercises.harder: Hold stretches 30 seconds each
warnings: Stop any stretch causing sharp pain
Don't force left shoulder beyond comfort

exercises.name: Seated Warm-up Circuit
exercises.description: Combination warm-up reviewing key movements from the week
steps: Ankle pumps x 10 (from Day 1)
Seated marching x 10 per leg (from Day 1)
Knee extensions x 8 per leg (from Day 2)
Torso rotations x 6 each side (from Day 3)
Shoulder rolls x 10 (from throughout week)
Move smoothly from one exercise to next with minimal rest
tips: This reviews what you've learned this week
Notice what feels easier now vs Monday
Keep movements controlled and purposeful
This is a good standalone warm-up for any future exercise
exercises.easier: Take breaks between each exercise, or reduce reps by half
exercises.harder: Do circuit twice, or increase reps
warnings: Stop if any exercise causes pain
This should feel moderately challenging but doable

exercises.name: Standing Balance Holds (Progressed)
exercises.description: Your most important exercise - progressed version of Day 1's standing hold
steps: Stand at counter, spouse nearby
Both hands lightly on counter
Stand tall, weight distributed on both feet
Hold this position for 20 seconds (progressed from 15 seconds)
Then, if feeling stable, try this: lift just ONE finger off counter at a time
Each time you lift a finger, you're relying more on leg balance, less on arms
See if you can get to using just 3-4 fingers for support
Rest fully between sets
tips: This is your progress test - compare to Monday's version
The finger-lifting is OPTIONAL but try it - you might surprise yourself
Focus on standing tall through both legs
This is exactly the balance you use when walking with your cane
If 20 seconds feels easy, that's GREAT news - you're ready for week 2 progressions
exercises.easier: Keep all 10 fingers on counter, or reduce hold to 15 seconds
exercises.harder: Hold 30 seconds, or get down to just 2-3 fingers touching
warnings: Spouse must be present
Stop if dizzy or unstable
Never go to zero hand support in week 1

exercises.name: Functional Task Practice: Simulated Activities
exercises.description: Practice movements that mimic real daily activities you want to improve
steps: Task 1 - Reaching high: Stand with support, reach up with right arm as if getting item from shelf, repeat 5 times, then try with left arm assisted
Task 2 - Picking up: Stand with support, safely bend and reach down to pick up object from chair seat (not floor yet), repeat 5 times
Task 3 - Walking prep: Stand with support, practice shifting weight side to side as if taking steps, 10 shifts
Task 4 - Turning: Stand with support, practice small turns to right and left (like checking blind spot), 5 each direction
Take breaks as needed between tasks
tips: These aren't 'exercises' - they're life skills
Notice which tasks feel easier/harder
This shows you where you've improved and what needs more work
Think about how these relate to: kitchen work, dressing, bathroom activities
Week 2 will build on whichever tasks felt hardest today
exercises.easier: Sit for the tasks instead of standing, or reduce reps to 3 each
exercises.harder: Reduce support (lighter hand touch), or add difficulty like reaching farther
warnings: Spouse must be present
Don't bend to floor level - only to chair seat height
Stop if unstable or dizzy

exercises.name: Left Arm & Hand Dexterity Work
exercises.description: Dedicated time for left hand practice - building toward your goal of improved daily function
equipment: Various objects: large buttons, coins, playing cards, therapy putty if available
steps: Large grasp practice: Pick up and release larger objects (water bottle, ball) x 10
Finger coordination: Try to pick up playing cards one at a time, even if you need right hand assist
Opposition practice: Try to touch left thumb to each fingertip in sequence, use right hand to help position if needed, repeat 5 times
Putty work: If you have therapy putty, squeeze and release 10 times with left hand
Functional grasp: Practice holding fork, spoon, cup - items you use daily
All exercises: right hand can assist, but ask left hand to contribute more each time
tips: Hand recovery is often slower than leg recovery - that's normal
Every bit of voluntary movement is your brain rewiring
Focus intense mental attention on left hand during this
Small improvements compound over weeks and months
This directly works toward your goal of better daily task function
Don't get frustrated - celebrate any movement, no matter how small
exercises.easier: Use only larger objects, let right hand do more assisting
exercises.harder: Try smaller objects, reduce right hand assistance
warnings: Never force fingers closed
Stop if hand cramping occurs
Some fatigue is normal, sharp pain is not

exercises.name: Full Body Relaxation & Stretching
exercises.description: Comprehensive cool-down and week 1 celebration
steps: Seated full body scan: Close eyes, bring attention to each body part from toes to head, notice what worked hard this week
Gentle neck stretches: All directions, 15 seconds each
Shoulder and arm stretches: Review from earlier sessions, hold each 20 seconds
Torso side bends and gentle twists: 20 seconds each
Hip and leg stretches: Hamstrings, hip flexors, calves - 20 seconds each
Ankle and foot circles: Both directions
Finish: 10 deep, slow breaths - in through nose for 4 counts, hold for 2, out through mouth for 6 counts
Final moment: Acknowledge your hard work this week
tips: You completed week 1 - that's a real achievement
Your body has been learning all week - this rest helps consolidate it
Notice areas that feel less tense than they did Monday
Recovery happens during rest, not just during exercise
Next week will build on everything you learned this week
Take tomorrow (Saturday) off from structured exercise - gentle walking if you feel good
exercises.easier: Shorter holds, or skip any painful stretches
exercises.harder: Hold stretches 30 seconds, add more repetitions
warnings: Never force any stretch
This should feel relaxing, not stressful

exercises.name: Seated Marching with Resistance Band
exercises.description: Progressed version of week 1 marching - adding resistance to strengthen hip flexors
steps: Sit tall, loop resistance band around both feet at arch level
Hold band ends in hands for tension control
Lift right knee against band resistance, hold 2 seconds
Lower with control
Lift left knee against resistance (will be harder), hold 2 seconds
Use hands to adjust band tension - lighter for left leg if needed
Continue alternating
tips: The resistance makes your hip muscles work harder
Left leg might need less resistance - that's fine, adjust the band
This builds on week 1's movement pattern with added challenge
You should feel this in front of thighs and hip flexors
exercises.easier: Use very light resistance, or remove band and do week 1 version
exercises.harder: Increase band tension, or hold knee lift for 4 seconds
warnings: Don't use so much resistance that form breaks down
Stop if hip pain occurs
